content.text: In recognition of the high volume of pleas to non-felony offenses which may be required to be taken on a given day in a local criminal court, the following questions extracted from the recommended plea colloquy provide, in the discretion of the court, a shorter, albeit sufficient, plea colloquy. [cite: 2]
However, even for non-felony offense, the expanded colloquy or parts thereof may be appropriate. [cite: 3]
Sentences in brackets are recommended but not required by law. [cite: 4]
Have you spoken with your lawyer about your case, about pleading guilty and its consequences? [cite: 5]
Are you satisfied with the services of your lawyer? [cite: 6]
The allegations of (name of crime) are (specify). [cite_start]Is that true? [cite: 7]
Do you plead guilty to (specify name of offense, and if so, and not already on the record, the court may add: â€œwhich is in satisfaction of (specify the more serious charge))? [cite: 8]
Do you understand that the sentence will be: (specify)? [cite: 9]

Do you understand that by pleading guilty, you waive your right to a trial [by jury] where you would have the right to confront and cross-examine witnesses and to remain silent and not to incriminate yourself? [cite: 10]

content.condition: If you are not a citizen of the United States

question.text: Do you wish to plead guilty, regardless of whether the plea in whole or in part results in your deportation, exclusion from the United States or denial of naturalization? [cite: 12]

content.text: Are you pleading guilty voluntarily, of your own free will and choice? [cite: 13]
The plea is acceptable to the Court. [cite: 13]

content.title: Representation by Counsel
content.text: Cases like People v Conceicao, People v Pellegrino, and People v Sougou indicate that the record should show the defendant is actively represented by an attorney, had a fair opportunity to consult with the lawyer about the plea and its consequences, and, if applicable, that the plea is in satisfaction of a more serious charge. [cite: 14, 15]

content.title: Waiver of Trial Rights
content.text: The specification of the rights included within the waiver of the right to a trial (confrontation of witnesses, right to remain silent) are derived from Boykin v. Alabama, 395 U.S. 238 (1969). [cite: 16]

content.title: Validity of Plea
content.text: The Court of Appeals has held that failing to recite these specific rights word-for-word (in haec verba) will not invalidate the plea if the 'record as a whole affirmatively shows that the defendant intentionally relinquished those rights.' [cite: 17] [cite_start]However, it is best practice to advise the defendant expressly of the rights being waived to avoid ambiguity and the need for an appellate court to search the record. [cite: 18]
